questions.text: Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of glutamate at its receptors in the central nervous system?

options.label: A
options.text: It inhibits metabotropic receptors, activating a G-protein, thus increasing cAMP levels.

options.label: B
options.text: It stimulates NMDA receptors, resulting in an influx of calcium ions.

options.label: C
options.text: It inhibits AMPA receptors, preventing sodium influx.

options.label: D
options.text: It stimulates kainate receptors, thus decreasing chloride ion permeability.

questions.correct_answer: B. It stimulates NMDA receptors, resulting in an influx of calcium ions.
questions.explanation:
Type

Subtype

Features

Functions

Ionotropic receptors

AMPA

(Alpha-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methylisoxazole-4-propionate)

(Option C)
  • Influx of Na+ and efflux of K+.
  • It has a low permeability for Ca2+.

Produces fast excitatory postsynaptic potential.


 

Kainate receptor

(Option D)

Influx of Na+ and Ca2+

Aids in excitatory neurotransmission

NMDA receptor

(N-methyl-D-aspartate)

(Option B)

Allows large influx of Ca2+ and Na+

Unique Features:

  • Glycine Binding: Essential for receptor response to glutamate.
  • Mg²⁺ Block: At normal membrane potentials, the channel is blocked by extracellular Mg²⁺. This block is removed during depolarisation by adjacent AMPA and kainate receptors.
  • EPSP: Slower than AMPA/kainate receptors-induced EPSP.

Involved in synaptic plasticity, memory, and learning and can cause excitotoxicity in excess.

Metabotropic receptors

(Option A)

Presynaptic (mGluR2-4,6-8):

Involved in limiting glutamate release.

Activation leads to changes in second messengers:

  • IP3 and DAG: Increased intracellular levels.
  • cAMP: Decreased intracellular levels.

Modulate synaptic plasticity and neurotransmission indirectly through second messengers.

Postsynaptic (mGluR1,5):

Involved in synaptic plasticity.

  • Ionotropic receptors
  • AMPA receptor
  • Kainate receptor
  • NMDA receptor
  • Metabotropic receptors
    • Presynaptic - (mGluR2-4,6-8)
    • Postsynaptic - (mGluR1,5)

questions.text: As illustrated below, in examining the effects of presynaptic inhibition and facilitation on action potentials, Ca²⁺ currents, and EPSPs (excitatory postsynaptic potential) ,which statement regarding the dashed line recordings is false? (solid lines for controls; dashed lines for inhibition/facilitation)

options.label: A
options.text: It can be produced by opening of voltage gated K+ channel

options.label: B
options.text: Produced due to enhanced Ca2+ entry in the presynaptic neuron.

options.label: C
options.text: The effect is produced by GABA

options.label: D
options.text: Produced due to increases Cl− conductance

questions.correct_answer: B. Produced due to enhanced Ca2+ entry in the presynaptic neuron.

questions.text: Feedforward Inhibition is seen in
questions.explanation:
Feature

Feedback Inhibition

Feedforward Inhibition

Definition

Inhibition where the output of a process inhibits its own production.

Inhibition where an excitatory neuron directly inhibits another neuron in response to input.

Mechanism

The end product of a metabolic pathway inhibits an enzyme involved in the pathway.

An excitatory neuron activates an inhibitory neuron and then inhibits a downstream neuron.

Function

It helps maintain homeostasis by regulating the production of substances.

Anticipates and prevents excessive excitation in neural circuits.

Example

The inhibition of an enzyme in a metabolic pathway by its end product (e.g., ATP inhibiting phosphofructokinase).

In the cerebellum, excitatory inputs inhibit output neurons to prevent overexcitation.

questions.text: In presynaptic inhibition, which neurotransmitter is most commonly responsible for inhibiting synaptic transmission at the presynaptic terminal?
questions.explanation:
Features

Indirect Inhibition

Direct Inhibition

Site of action

Presynaptic terminal

Postsynaptic neuron

Primary mechanism

Reduces neurotransmitter release.

Hyperpolarises or shunts postsynaptic neurons..

Main neurotransmitter

GABA (primarily)

GABA, Glycine (Option D)

Receptor types involved

Mainly GABA-B receptors

GABA-A, Glycine receptors

Spatial effect

It can affect multiple synapses from the same axon

Localized to specific synapses

Onset and duration

Can be longer-lasting

Usually, rapid onset and offset

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman has fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens throughout the day. Tests show a decremental response to repetitive nerve stimulation, improvement with edrophonium, and antibodies against neuromuscular junction proteins. What is the primary pathophysiological mechanism in this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased acetylcholine release from motor nerve terminals

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced functional acetylcholine receptors on the postsynaptic membrane

options.label: C
options.text: Antibodies blocking voltage-gated calcium channels on presynaptic terminals

questions.correct_answer: B. Reduced functional acetylcholine receptors on the postsynaptic membrane
questions.explanation:
Feature

Myasthenia Gravis

Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS)

Primary autoantibody target

Acetylcholine receptors

Voltage-gated calcium channels (Option C)

Pathophysiology

Reduced postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors (Option B)

Decreased presynaptic acetylcholine release (Options A and D)

Fatigue pattern

Worsens with activity

Improves with brief exercise.

Reflexes

Normal or mildly reduced

Reduced or absent may improve after exercise.

Repetitive nerve stimulation

Decremental response.

Incremental response.

Response to edrophonium

Improves symptoms.

Little to no improvement.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of events at the neuromuscular junction?

options.label: A
options.text: Ca2+ influx → ACh release → End-plate potential → Muscle contraction

options.label: B
options.text: ACh release → Ca2+ influx → End-plate potential → Muscle contraction

options.label: C
options.text: End-plate potential → Ca2+ influx → ACh release → Muscle contraction

options.label: D
options.text: ACh release → End-plate potential → Ca2+ influx → Muscle contraction

questions.correct_answer: A. Ca2+ influx → ACh release → End-plate potential → Muscle contraction

questions.text: Slow Type inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP) is generated by?
questions.explanation:
IPSP Type

Channel

Region

Slow IPSP

Opening of K+ Channel (Option A)

Autonomic ganglia, smooth muscles, cardiac muscles.

Fast IPSP

Entry of Cl- Channel (Option C)

All parts of the CNS.

questions.text: What is the primary effect of an inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP) on a neuron's excitability?

options.label: A
options.text: Increases the rate of Neurotransmitter release

options.label: B
options.text: Decreases membrane potential, closer to firing threshold

options.label: C
options.text: Increases membrane potential, farther from firing threshold

questions.correct_answer: C. Increases membrane potential, farther from firing threshold

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents with neurological symptoms following a Cerebrovascular accident. Imaging confirms ischemic damage in the brain. Elevated levels of glutamate are found in the extracellular of the brain. Which of the following statements about glutamate-induced cytotoxicity is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Cleared primarily by K+dependent systems in neurons

options.label: B
options.text: Causes neuronal death by excessive Na+ influx

options.label: C
options.text: Cytotoxicity due to excessive Ca2+ influx

options.label: D
options.text: Elevated Na+ stimulates astrocytes to remove glutamate

questions.correct_answer: C. Cytotoxicity due to excessive Ca2+ influx

questions.text: During the generation of excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP), which of the following movements of ions occur at the postsynaptic membrane?
Which subtype of GABA receptors mediate fast inhibitory postsynaptic potentials through the entry of Cl- into neurons? GABA-A GABA-B GABA-C
questions.explanation:
Type

Receptor subtype

Subunit

Distribution

Mechanism

Inotropic receptor

GABA- A

Pentamers of various combinations: 6 α, 4 β, 4 γ, 1 δ, 1 ε

CNS

Activation allows Cl– entry into neurons, mediating fast inhibitory postsynaptic potentials (IPSP)

GABA- C

Pentamers of three ρ subunits in various combinations

Almost exclusively in the retina.

G-protein coupled receptor

GABA- B

No specific subunit composition

CNS

Linked via G-proteins: Gi inhibits adenylyl cyclase to open the K+ channel, Go inhibits or delays Ca2+ influx.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male presents with a neurodegenerative condition involving impaired glutamate regulation. Which type of glial cell is primarily involved in glutamate regulation?
questions.explanation:
Oligodendrocytes (Option D)

Form myelin sheath in CNS neurons.

Astrocytes (Option B)
  • Support and protect neurons, provide nutrition, and control levels of glutamate.
  • It is of 2 types:
    • Fibrous astrocytes (found in white matter)
    • Protoplasmic astrocytes (found in grey matter)

Schwann cells (Option A)

Form myelin sheath in PNS neurons.

questions.text: Match the following neurotransmitters with their site of production in CNS. A. Acetylcholine (ACh) 1. Raphe nuclei B. Norepinephrine (NE) 2. Nucleus basalis of Meynert C. Dopamine 3. Locus ceruleus D. Serotonin 4. Substantia nigra
questions.explanation:
Neurotransmitters

Source

Description

Acetylcholine (ACh)

Nucleus basalis of Meynert
  • Associated with Muscle contraction, Memory and REM sleep
  • NT* for Sweat glands

Norepinephrine (NE)

Locus ceruleus

Regulates wakefulness and alertness.

Dopamine

Substantia nigra
  • Destruction causes Parkinson’s disease.
  • NT* of reward and addiction.

Serotonin

Raphe nuclei
  • Regulation of mood, sleep, and appetite.
  • The highest concentration is in Platelets, enterochromaffin cells, and myenteric plexus.

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is primarily responsible for inhibiting motor neuron activity at the level of the spinal cord to regulate muscle tone and reflexes?
25-year-old patient with generalized anxiety disorder presents with persistent insomnia. Which neurotransmitter is targeted to promote relaxation and reduce excitability?
questions.explanation:
Excitatory

Inhibitory
  • Glutamate (Major excitatory NT)
  • Aspartate (Less common)
  • GABA (Brain)
  • Glycine (Spinal cord)

Produces Excitatory Post Synaptic Potential (EPSP)

  • Fast EPSP: Due to Na or Ca Influx
  • Slow EPSP: Due to K+ channel closure

Produces Inhibitory Post Synaptic Potential (IPSP)

  • Fast IPSP: Due to Cl-Entry
  • Slow IPSP: Due to K+ channel opening

Class 1

Choline & Acetyl CoA: Acetylcholine (ACh)

Class 2

Biogenic Amines: Norepinephrine, Dopamine, Serotonin, Histamine

Class 3

Amino Acid Neurotransmitters: Glutamate, GABA, Aspartate, Glycine

Class 4

Purines and Gases: ATP, NO, CO

Peptide Neurotransmitters: Substance P, Neuropeptide Y

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with severe muscle stiffness and spasms, including trismus and rigidity, after stepping on a rusty nail two weeks ago. Which toxin is responsible for these symptoms by interfering with neurotransmitter release at the neuromuscular junction?
Which protein, essential for regulating neurotransmitter release at the neuromuscular junction, prevents the premature fusion of synaptic vesicles?
Which of the following types of vesicle at the synaptic terminal contain glutamate neurotransmitter ?
questions.explanation:
Types of vesicles

Neurotransmitters

Small clear vesicles

Acetylcholine, GABA, glutamate

Small dense core vesicles (Option C)

Catecholamines(eg:dopamine,epinephrine and norepinephrine)

Large dense core vesicles (Option B)

Neuropeptides

questions.text: A researcher studying the precision of synaptic connections between neurons focuses on how specific neurons target each other for communication. Which of the following concepts refers to the precise targeting of synaptic connections to ensure accurate neuronal communication?
A researcher studying synaptic transmission observes that communication at a particular synapse is both rapid and bidirectional. What is the most likely synapse?
questions.explanation:
Aspects

Electrical synapse

Chemical synapse (Option A)

Occurrence

Rare

Most common

Width of synaptic cleft

Narrow

Wide

Neurotransmitters

Absent

Present

Gap junctions

Present

Absent

Synaptic transmission

No time delay

Time delay is present

Transmission direction

Bidirectional

Unidirectional

Component

Pre-synaptic and Post-synaptic membranes (connected by gap junctions)

Pre-synaptic cleft and post-synaptic cleft

Types

-

3 types:

  • Axodendritic (Option C)
  • Axoaxonal (Option B)
  • Axosomatic

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient complains of visual disturbances and difficulty walking. On detailed examination, the patient is diagnosed with multiple sclerosis that occurs due to demyelination of neurons. Which of the following cells is involved in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Characteristics

Peripheral nervous system

Central nervous system

Cells involved in Myelination

One Schwann cell for one neuron.

One Oligodendrocyte for multiple neurons.

Demyelinating disease

Localised disease (e.g., Guillain-Barré Syndrome)

Diffuse disease (e.g., Multiple Sclerosis)

Covering of unmyelinated neuron

Surrounded by the Schwann cell process.

Bare (no myelin sheath)
